facts: Water boils at a lower temperature on high mountains because the air pressure is lower.
Baking powder makes dough rise by creating bubbles of carbon dioxide gas when it gets wet and warm.
Salt can raise the boiling point of water, but the change is so small in cooking that it mostly affects flavor instead.
Cast iron pans hold heat very well, which helps foods brown evenly after the pan is hot.
Letting meat rest after cooking helps keep it juicier because the juices spread back through the meat.
Sugar helps baked goods turn brown through caramelization and the Maillard reaction, which also makes new flavors.
Stirring a pot cools it slightly because it moves hot liquid away from the bottom and helps heat spread out.
